fig.label: Figure 1
fig.sd-panel: A. Schematic exon structure of Stim1 gene with conventional exons depicted in grey. Highlighted in red is the alternative exon 11 (named A), and additional mutually exclusive splicing of exon 13 (named L, green) or exon 13 (named B, blue). Alternative usage of 5'UTR regions are indicated with alt1 and alt2. Arrows indicate schematic location of primers, B. Schematic representation of primer annealing sites on the coding mRNA.
C Analytic PCR with primers flanking the splice site using cDNA's of tissues or cells as indicated. L denotes exon L of STIM1L, A denotes additional exon A.
D. qRT-PCR of exonA specific reaction normalized to sum of exon specific and wt specific (total) Stim1 (± SD) in tissues using cDNA derived from 3-4 mice.
E. Schematic protein structure of STIM1 displaying functional motives. Domain A (red) is located 8 amino acids downstream of the inhibitory domain (ID, yellow) after aa 491.
F. Evolutional conservation of domain A. Identical amino acids within black boxes.
G. Western blot showing Stim1 and Stim1A following heterologous expression in HEK293DKO (left); right panel: quantification from 4 transfections, mean ± SD.

H. Endogenous levels of Stim1 in testes from C57BL/6 wt and splice deficient 10A mice, using an antibody detecting the N-term of STIM1, detecting STIM1A (A, red arrow), STIM1 and its glycosylated (wt) and unglycosylated (wt gl.) form.

fig.label: Figure 9
fig.sd-panel: Left image: SOCE mediated by STIM1 and ORAI1 leads to Ca2+ influx, recruitment of the AKAP79/NFAT signaling complex and the phosophodiesterase PDE8. Locally recruited PDE8 reduces cAMP at ER-PM junctions. The AKAP79 signalosome recruitment is instable due to limited membrane PIP2 levels. CAN: Calcineurin. Right image: SOCE mediated by STIM1A and ORAI1 leads to reduced Ca2+ influx due to destabilized gating and hampers recruitment of PDE8. Reduced recruitment leads to reduced local cAMP degradation, which enhances PIP2 levels by activating PIPkinases. Increased levels of PIP2 stabilize the AKAP79 signalosome, enabling more efficient NFAT translocation.
